sentence.Network_en: It is an important moment, crowning the efforts of the Cup organisers.
sentence.Network_cn: 这是个重要时刻，它使得优胜杯赛组织者的努力圆满告捷。

sentence.Network_en: The cathedral is the crowning glory of the city.
sentence.Network_cn: 大教堂是这座城市至高无上的骄傲。

sentence.Network_en: Her crowning glory is her hair.
sentence.Network_cn: 最使她容貌生辉的是她的头发.

entry.tran: 王冠;皇冠;冕;(戴在头上的)冠状物
entry.def: A crown is a circular ornament, usually made of gold and jewels, which a king or queen wears on their head at official ceremonies. You can also use crown to refer to anything circular that is worn on someone's head.

entry.tran: 王国政府;王国;(英国刑事案件中的)公诉人
entry.def: The government of a country that has a king or queen is sometimes referred to as the Crown. In British criminal cases the prosecutor is the Crown .

example.ex: She says the sovereignty of the Crown must be preserved.
example.tran: 她说必须维护王国政府的主权。

entry.def: When a king or queen is crowned, a crown is placed on their head as part of a ceremony in which they are officially made king or queen.

example.ex: Elizabeth was crowned in Westminster Abbey on 2 June 1953...
example.tran: 伊丽莎白于1953年6月2日在威斯敏斯特大教堂加冕。

example.ex: Two days later, Juan Carlos was crowned king.
example.tran: 两天后，胡安·卡洛斯被加冕为国王。

entry.def: If one thing crowns another, it is on top of it.

example.ex: Here another rugged castle crowns the cliffs and crags.
example.tran: 这里又有一座高低不平的城堡建在悬崖绝壁之上。

example.ex: ...a very striking face, crowned by an abundance of hair.
example.tran: 一张非常标致的脸，长着一头浓密的头发

entry.def: Your crown is the top part of your head, at the back.

example.ex: He laid his hand gently on the crown of her head.
example.tran: 他把手轻轻放在她的头顶上。

entry.def: The crown of a hat is the part which covers the top of your head.
A crown was a British coin worth five shillings.
A crown is an artificial top piece fixed over a broken or decayed tooth.
In sport, winning an important competition is sometimes referred to as a crown .

example.ex: ...his dream of a fourth Wimbledon crown.
example.tran: 他梦想第四次获得温布尔登网球公开赛的冠军

entry.def: An achievement or event that crowns something makes it perfect, successful, or complete.

example.ex: It is an important moment, crowning the efforts of the Cup organisers...
example.tran: 这是个重要时刻，它使得优胜杯赛组织者的努力圆满告捷。

example.ex: The summit was crowned by the signing of the historic START treaty.
example.tran: 此次峰会以签订具有历史性意义的《削减进攻性战略武器条约》宣告圆满成功。

entry.def: If you crown your career with a success or achievement, you have a final success or achievement which is greater than all the others you have had.

example.ex: He went on to crown a distinguished career in radio and television with his book 'The Price of Victory'.
example.tran: 凭借《胜利的代价》一书，在广播和电视事业上成就杰出的他再创辉煌。

means.word_mean: 1. representing a level of the highest possible achievement or attainment;
2. forming or providing a crown or summit;

sentences.sentence: "the crowning star on a Christmas tree"

auth_sentence.content: There, modesty is the crowning glory of sentiment.
auth_sentence.res_content: There, modesty is the crowning glory of sentiment.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: There, modesty is the crowning glory of sentiment.

auth_sentence.content: Won't that be Mr. Obama's crowning second-term achievement?
auth_sentence.res_content: Won't that be Mr. Obama's crowning second-term achievement?
auth_sentence.res_content_con: Won't that be Mr. Obama's crowning second-term achievement?

auth_sentence.content: But Lady Mary Crawley in Downton was the crowning part.
auth_sentence.res_content: But Lady Mary Crawley in Downton was the crowning part.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: But Lady Mary Crawley in Downton was the crowning part.
